content.description:
Access granite starts on an awesome finger crack close to the arête. This finger crack ends just before a ledge, once on the ledge either climb the corner or the face to access the  next larger ledge. There is a nice crack in the middle of the final slab, climb this crack to the top.  This is a fun route and is a convenient way to access the top of Welcome to Welsford.

Just left and around the corner of W2W.
This climb take a range of gear, bring a rack.

Start in the corner or on the right arête. A few small moves will get you to a stance and a first piece of gear, stay in the right trending corner all the way to the large ledge 12 feet from the top of the wall, at this point you will want to escape left on to the slab make one move getting in to the corner and finish at the trees.

Follow an obvious corner through a blocky section.
Bring a rack

This climb starts on the crack right of the corner. Pull up on to the ledge and use both the face crack and the corner crack to ascend the wall.  
 A great variation is to climb the second part with out using the corner crack, it takes good gear and will keep you on your toes. 5.10.  

This is the further climb to the left on the Hex wall.
Takes good gear bring a rack.

This climb starts in a small corner behind the sawed off stump. Follow the corner up to the ledge with the very wide crack in the corner. Climb the crack while staying out of the chimney.

in the corner left of W2W.
Bring a rack. The last section takes a big nut you can place from the ledge and then a #4 cam at the top.

Climb the easy corner on the far side of hex wall leading up to a large Fir tree. Easy climbing with good protection.

Far right side of Hex wall. 
Small rack.

This climb follows the obvious finger crack dihedral up the left side of the arête. The gear is a little thin steeping off the ground but then you are able to place good pro from the first stance. Follow the thin seam to the roof where the thin crack disappears and some wider cracks offer protection and fantastic exposed moves through the roof. The climb moves slightly left after the roof to the corner system. Follow the corner system to the ledge where you step left and finish up the dihedral to the tree anchor.

This is a very thin crack that follows the left side of the arête.
Bring some tiny cams and a rack.

This tradition climbs follow a corner crack system that has a magnitude of different sizes and finishes on a deathly looking flake. The flake appears very solid and you have two options out and around or up and over.

Down a slight hill to the right of Dealers choice and royal flash there is a corner that opens to offwidth size around 20 feet and has a large flake at the top.
Bring a rack and a #4 cam.

First climb easy peasy to access the ledge. The climb starts on a large flake with good protection behind it. Then continue up a series of horizontal cracks about 4 feet apart with good protection finishing off final
 slab and a tree anchor. 

Starts on the ledge after climbing easy-peasy around the fir tree. 
Small rack with extra finger size cams and smaller.

The crux is getting out of the corner and onto the first ledge.  Get a piece in high in the first corner crack and make sure your belayer is paying attention. The whole climb is good but the beginning and final 10 feet are highlights.

Start 5 feet right of the Rapid Transit corner.  Climb up a thin block and get into the corner crack to the right.  Continue up the corner until you can reach a skinny tree on a sloping ledge.  Pull up onto the ledge and continue up the ridge to a slab.  Follow the natural line up and right to a small roof.  Pass under the roof then move up to a Hemlock tree.
Single rack to 3".  One fixed pin near the top.  Get up on the ledge, build an anchor on one of the trees and belay the second.  Rap straight down to the base of CSI.

A bold climb in the same style as its neighbour to the left; climbs like a sport climb but entirely protected on gear. Less sustained but more powerful than W2W.
Climb the start of Squeeze Whiz to the large block ledge. From the ledge, move left around the arête and climb awesome bouldery sequences up the overhanging wall, trending right towards a vertical crack that opens into a V groove.

Shares the start with Squeeze Whiz
Some small nuts and various cam sizes. A #5 was used at the block ledge.

A steep start leads to a fun, easy romp up a corner system.

Locate a clean corner just right of Hands, Fingers, Knees and Toes. This is just right and below a huge flake sticking out near the top. Rap the route or downclimb.
Finish on a big spruce up and right of the huge protruding flake that looks like it will break off but is actually really solid.  Single rack to 2" if you feel like placing gear.

Start on the splitter corner cracks and move to the ledge, stand on the ledge and finish up the cracks and vertical rails.

Located on the far left end of the Hex wall. it's the right most climb on the little wall with all the cracks.
This climbs take a verity of gear I recommend having a #3 cam.

This climb starts in the same corner as thin to win, climb the corner for 15 to access the crack on the steep left wall. Climb the obvious crack over the bulge onto the ledge; follow the arête to the top This climb is not easily top roped.

Located on the Hex wall left of W2W.
Take med cams and a set of nuts.

Climb Easy Peasy. At the very top of the corner, continue straight up the face past a small roof. Pull up onto a small slab and finish up the zig-zagging crack.

At the far right end of Hex wall. Climb Easy Peasy to start. Climbs the face left of Horizontal Heaven.
Standard rack to #2

Climb the nice thin hand crack up under the block in the alcove. Make a funky move around the chock boulder, and stand up on to the ledge. Move to the back of the ledge and look left you will see the light. Make a few chimney moves so you can see your exist then squeeze like a mother fucker towards the light hopefully you make it. Recommended to have a 30in waist or smaller.

Just right of W2W.
This climb is different; Recommended pro is to carry a few cams sizes .25-#4 Maybe a #5. When you get in to the cave/ledge you may want to remove any additional gear because the squeeze is that thin. The second may want to toss the gear down before the squeeze.

climbs.name: Steve and Joes Most Excellent Route

content.description:
5' right of Royal Flash.  This is the third route in the series starting from the left.  Climb up to a small left below a slabby face with a thin crack on the left side.  Make a mantle move halfway up and finish in the trees.  Very clean rock and good protection.  This climb is not in the guidebook, but given how clean it is, it has obviously been well climbed.



Start just below the slabby face with a thin crack on the left side.

The crack takes small cams or nuts.

This climb follows the broken looking corner under a slightly over vertical wall. The corner offers good protection all the way to the last ledge where the chimney is.when you get to the final ledge step down into the chimney make a few awkward steps up onto some chock stone/rocks and exit out of the top.

Left of W2W,
Bring a rack. The chimney takes a big nut you can place from the ledge and then a #4 cam at the top.

Climb up the obvious corner for the climb Dont FitLayback it!. At the last ledge there are a series of flakes on the left wall; a bouldery start will get you to some gear placements. Finish up the first flake on to a ledge make a balancy move to the left to access the next flake, and then punch it to the top.

This climb starts half way up "Thin to Win". And follows the flakes on the vertical wall.
This climb does take gear but not a lot. Place gear when you can and the crux is protected. Small to Med cams.

What an impressive 70 foot slightly overhanging climb that follows a thin crack starting on the left side of the wall and trends right before finishing at the top of the wall. While the thin crack offers enough protection to climb this traditionally the route is mostly face climbing with few good rests. 
  The starting hold is height dependent so there is a cheater stone build to start the route.     
 It would not be a bad idea to TR this and look at the gear before trying the red point if this is really your limit,the gear is tricky to place in some spots but bomber.  
  
 This is one of the only climbs in New Brunswick that is overhanging enough that you can climb it while it's  raining.

This is the only climb located on the amazing over hanging wall.
Thin- Bring 2 sets of small nuts one set of regular nuts and double cams up to a #3 orange master cam (purple .5 BD cam). Optional #1 BD cam 1 foot from top.

The Hex wall is a great wall reaching heights of 70ft and has one of the best views of c-lane from the other side of the valley. The Hex wall has a few 2 to 4 star traditional crack climbs that provide fun movement and great gear placements. This cliff is in the shade most of the day and is a great place for the hot summer days.  
   The Hex wall host one of Welsford most physically demanding overhanging traditional routes Welcome to Welsford and also one of the most mentally demanding routes Squeeze Whiz that consists of 5.8 climbing and 30 feet of squeezing through a thin chimney like slot.   
  
 The Hex wall can be accessed from the top by bush whacking to the right of the great roof until you reach the top of the cliff. There are a few mini cliffs, loose rocks and holes so watch your step.
